DataElement.preferredName: Gastric Cancer AJCC Edition 8 Pathologic Distant Metastasis M Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the distant metastasis for gastric carcinoma based on clinical stage information combined with operative findings, and evidence obtained from pathology review when surgery is the first definitive therapy, using AJCC Ed. 8 criteria.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Relating to the stomach._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Relating to the stomach.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  M refers to the presence of metastasis.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 12/3/18 tmt transferred context from NCIP. Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/7/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Gastric Carcinoma American Joint Committee on Cancer Edition 8 M Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of gastric cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v8 classification system. This staging system applies to all carcinomas that arise in the stomach. Gastrointestinal stromal tumors, sarcomas, lymphomas and well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumors (G1 and G2) are not staged using this staging system. (from AJCC 8th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._One criteria of the TNM staging system. M refers to the presence of metastasis._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
